participants.participant: John Colglazier, Vice President, Investor Relations and Communications
James T. Hackett, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer

plist.p: Good day ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2007 Anadarko Petroleum Corporation's Earnings Conference Call. My name in Eric, I will be your coordinator for today. I would now like to turn your presentation over to your host for today's call that is Mr. John Colglazier. Please go ahead, sir.

Well, thanks, Eric. Good morning and thank you for joining us today for our fourth quarter and year-end 2007 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call today are Jim Hackett, our Chairman and CEO, and other executives who will be available to answer your questions later in the call. Consistent with previous reporting periods, we have included a lot of information in our operations report, which is posted on our website.

Before I turn the call over to Jim, I need to remind you of certain aspects in our forward-looking statement. This presentation contains our best and most reasonable estimates and information. However, a number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially. You should read our full disclosure on forward-looking statements in our presentation slides, our latest 10-K, other filings and press releases for the risk factors associated with our business. In addition, we'll reference a non-GAAP cash flow measure, so be sure to see the reconciliation in our earnings release. We also encourage you to read the cautionary note to U.S. Investors contained in the presentation slides for the call.
With that, let me turn the call over to Jim Hackett.

Thanks, John and good morning, everyone. We delivered as you see a strong fourth quarter in a remarkable 2007. Today I want to highlight some of our more notable achievements and take a quick look at what to expect in 2008.

We made a number of commitments to our stakeholders after the acquisitions of Kerr-McGee and Western Gas Resources and through solid and timely execution; we fulfilled and in many cases exceeded those commitments. I want to personally thank our employees who have worked so hard to build value for all of us by executing Anadarko strategic plan.

Among our accomplishments since the acquisitions; first we've transformed our portfolio and reduced the leverage. If you recall we initially anticipated we would need to issue between 5 and $7.5 billion of equity in conjunction with the divestitures of approximately 7.5 to $10 billion of assets over 18 to 24 month period. However, asset monetization program exceeded expectations and within 18 months we generated nearly $15 billion to reach our year-end 2007 long-term net debt target resulting in the issuance of zero equity. We now have a high graded asset base geared toward more consistent and predictable production growth and less capital intensity.

And we'll continue to reduce leverage in 2008 from free cash flow and other normal course activities. Second, we increased production guidance from our retained properties on three separate occasions during 2007. And we exceeded our most recent guidance by producing 13 million barrels of oil equivalent or 7% above the midpoint of our original full year projection on our retained properties. Third, we improved our cost structure throughout the year, and I will discuss this in more detail later in the call.

During 2007, we also completed a conversion of our accounting method from full cost to successful efforts. This was a monumental task never previously undertaken by a company of our size, but we believe we will enhance our decision-making ability and was clearly worth the effort.

Turning our attention to fourth quarter operations. As I mentioned, we exceeded the high-end of the revised production guidance by 1 million barrels of oil equivalent. The reported volumes of 53 million barrels of oil equivalent represented a 13% sequential increase over the third quarter.

This out performance was primarily driven by Independence Hub and other offshore properties. Independence Hub was a significant milestone in the year with startup occurring on time and on budget. Further, we delivered on an aggressive ramp up schedule to reach our targeted peak production rate of 1 billion cubic feet per day. Although our current run rate is in the range of 850 to 900 million cubic feet per day, we continue to advise you at an 80% run time factor adjusted for our working interest at 60% and reduced by the applicable one-eighth royalties to estimate our net volumes at Independence Hub.

We also achieved record production from several of our onshore fields during the fourth quarter. Our Greater Natural Buttes area achieved a high daily gross operated production of approximately 245 million cubic feet per day. Also in the Greater Natural Buttes area we bought the Chapita processing plant online in the fourth quarter adding 250 million cubic feet a day of processing capacity to the area, which will help us to further increase our record production volumes in 2008. We also achieved new gross production records at our coalbed methane properties in Wyoming's Powder River Basin of approximately 250 million cubic feet a day in late December.

In addition, we have already added 200 million cubic feet a day of gathering capacity to the Basin with the completion of the first phase of the Fort Union Gathering System expansion and we anticipate doubling the original line 650 million cubic feet a day of capacity by mid-year 2008.

Turning to our exploration program, they remain a key skill set in an important component of our portfolio. We announced the substantial fourth quarter discovery in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico at West Tonga. The well encountered more then 350 feet of net oil pay and three high-quality sub salt Miocene sands. We have begun unitization discussions with the Caesar and Tonga partners in our evaluating potential development program, where the discovery would be a subsea tieback to our 100% owned Constitution spar approximately eight miles to the West.

We are currently drilling the Green Bay prospects, which was spud in December and is targeting the lower Tertiary with an anticipated total depth of 30,500 feet. We operate the well with a 25% working interest. We expect to spud the Sturgis North prospect this month in which we own a 25% working interest and which offsets the earlier Sturgis discovery.

Internationally we had notable successes in 2007 with two large deepwater discoveries offshore Ghana at the Mahogany-1 and Shedua wells. We estimate the area has unbooked recoverable resources in the range of 200 million to more than 1 billion barrels of oil equivalent. To follow-up on the success, we're currently drilling the Odum number one exploration in the West Cape Three Points Block with a total depth of 10,500 feet. Offshore Brazil we're currently drilling our first Subsalt test at the Serpa prospect on Block 24 in the Espirito Santo Basin. This well has a targeted total depth of 19,500 feet with a 30% working interest.

Those are some of our operational highlights and as John said there is more detail available in the operations report that is posted on our website. As we laid out in our earnings release, adjusting for certain items affecting comparability, we had an excellent quarter underpinned by solid production performance and improved crude oil price differentials.

Earlier I mentioned our improving cost structure and I want to highlight one area in particular. Oil and gas operating expense was $4.40 per BOE in the quarter, which represents almost a 20% reduction from the third quarter and was well below our current guidance. This resulted from increased volumes with minimal incremental cost in fewer work over activities during the quarter.

We look at exploration expense in two categories. The first, which consists of dry hole expense and impairment of unproved properties, totaled $178 million for the quarter. The dry hole expense of $99 million was primarily associated with the Atlas Deep and Terrebonne prospects. The second category consists of G&G exploration overhead and delay rentals and totaled approximately $113 million.

As a company we met or exceeded most of our internal targets such as production volumes, reserve additions and share price performance relative to our peers. Accordingly our employees were rewarded through our formula driven bonus plan. Other than this performance-based compensation, our G&A costs were inline with guidance and vastly improved relative to 2006.

As mentioned in our earnings release excluding the effects of divestitures, we added approximately 250 million barrels of oil equivalent of proved reserves during 2007, most of which are associated with low risk infill drilling opportunities onshore and a Peregrino development in Brazil. We ended the year with an estimated 2.43 billion barrels of oil equivalent of proved reserves, approximately 67% of which are proved developed.

One detail to note on the categories on our reserve tables was that the guidance from the SEC has changed. Only new field discoveries or field boundary extensions will be classified as discoveries or extensions. Reserve adds representing new infill drilling opportunities will now be classified as revisions. Therefore, our reserve bookings in our large onshore resource play such as Greater Natural Buttes, Wattenberg and Pinedale/Jonah have been treated as positive revisions where as they would have been classified as extensions, discoveries and other additions in prior years.

While we did have some favorable price revisions excluding price provisions, we more than replaced production as we earlier committed to investors. We reported production of 212 million barrels of oil equivalent for the year, which includes about 15 million barrels of production associated with divested properties. Our costs incurred in exploration and development for the year were a little more than $3.8 billion. In addition to our earnings release, we also published details of our 2008 capital program in a separate news release.

We anticipate the 2008 capital expenditures including the expense exploration will be in the range of 4.5 to $4.7 billion. At our budgeted prices, which are significantly below strip pricing and equity analyst consensus estimates. We believe this is the appropriate expenditure level for Anadarko to continue monetizing the more than 7 billion barrels of net risked captured resources that we currently have in our portfolio.

However, we will evaluate raising budgeted CapEx levels in order to increase our exploration and appraisal programs if commodity prices remain strong. The budgeted capital program reflects our commitment to increase activity in the Rockies to expand deepwater exploration and to continue the expansion of our midstream infrastructure.

During 2008, we have guided to a production range of between 205 million barrels of oil equivalent and 210 million barrels of oil equivalent, an increase over the midpoint of the prior guidance that we issued in November. We also expect to add at least 225 million barrels of oil equivalent of proved reserves during the year and we currently anticipate E&P costs incurred to be in the range of 4 to $4.2 billion.

As I mentioned the capital program also includes an expansion of our deepwater exploration program in 2008. In the Gulf of Mexico we plan to drill between 6 and 8 prospects this year. Those include Green Bay and Sturgess, which I mentioned earlier in the call. We also have additional opportunities at the Heidelberg and Lyell prospects, which are located in the Miocene Fairway where we've had success with the Caesar Tonga and West Tonga discoveries.

To follow-up on our success offshore Ghana and in addition to the current Odum well, the partners have contracted for rigs, who enable us to drill up to an additional 5 to 7 wells this year. Offshore Brazil in addition to the current Serpa prospect we'll be drilling four more super-salt and sub-salt test in the Campos and Espírito Santo basins. And we have one deepwater well planned in the South China Sea on Block 43/11 adjacent to the large Husky gas discovery.

As part of our risk management strategy and similar to 2008, we see some potential volatility in 2009. The 2008 gas hedging position appears in our earnings release and gives us significant protection. To further protect ourselves against short-term downdrafts in U.S. gas markets, we have hedged approximately 500 million cubic feet a day for 2009. Using NYMEX costless 3-way collars with the floor of $7.50 per decatherm with an upside of up to $11 per decatherm.

In addition, because of the potential impact Rockies Express could have in the Mid-Continent Texas Gas markets we've increased our basis hedges for those areas as well for 2008 and 2009. Again there is more detailed information attached to the earnings release. We are pleased with the results and achievements of 2007 and look forward to a strong 2008. We are also excited for the opportunity to share the Anadarko story at our upcoming Investor Conference in New York on March 25 and we'll provide additional details on our company's E&P and Midstream operations at the conference. With that Eric, let's open it up for questions.
. Your first question comes from the line of Tom Gardner with Simmons and Company. Please proceed.
Good morning, Jim, John.
Good morning.

I have a question about REX; you had a lot of success in the Rockies, your gas production now approaching a Bcf a day. How has Rockies Express moving into operation impacted your Rockies production and how will it impact it going forward?

Hi, Tom this is Karl Kurz and Chuck Meloy is sitting here as he may join in this too, obviously with REX coming on line we've seen system pressures drop across the board in the Rockies. We've seen some very strong performance from our coal bed methane assets in the area. We're hitting record levels of production up to 700 million cubic feet a day in that. And so, we expect that continue to deload the area, obviously with the CBM, the water is the big issue, getting the water off the reservoirs, and as additional capacities are available, we will be to dewater and we expect to see continued strong performance.

Great. Now I understand, weather has been a factor with some – with respect to making additional well connections. In short, if you didn't have weather to deal or backup of system pressure, what would you be making in the Rockies? What does that look like?

You know, I ask that question to Chuck about every other day, and it's a hard one to answer, because, we're in the – you're dealing with the coalbed methane, which is a desorption process. So it's a matter how quick we can get the water off, and we can tell you that the Big George reservoirs continues to perform better than we expected. So, we are not going to give any predictions on what we think it will do, but we're optimistic that the Big George will still surprise us going forward.

Great. Jumping down to Carthage, I understand you have that first horizontal, probably have some production data there. Has that performed according to expectations and do you anticipate dedicating a rig full time to the horizontal development.
I am going to let Chuck talk about what's going on in Carthage, that's an exciting story for us.
Great. Thank you.

We have actually completed two horizontal wells in Carthage, both of which are performing at or above our expectations, we are now drilling our third well and with the data that we have we fully intend to run a complete rig line during 2008 in horizontal drilling.
Okay, great.

Let me add on the Carthage, a little bit to the G&G side, we have done some work G&G wise that we think gives us a way to identify some good fairways to place those horizontal wells in. So, we're excited about our ability to target good locations for horizontal wells in the Carthage.
Great. I will let someone else hop in. I do have some other questions; maybe I will follow up with John later.
Thank you.
You bet.
Your next question comes from the line of Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs. Please proceed.
Thank you. Good morning.
Good morning.

Following up on the previous question looking at CBM, with the Fort Union expansion now complete, do you see any constraints given that REX is on as well to showing consistent growth from CBM and can you put any numbers to where you see your net CBM production at year-end?

Brian, we now are in the process of dewatering the field again as we come back out of the cold spell and the shutdown of the Cheyenne Plains and what we see is a constant steady growth throughout the course of the year, as we get these wells dewatered. We haven't put out guidance with respect to actual expectations of increases, but we see it having throughout the course, feel very confident in how the wells have performed.
And it will be fair to say we have the CBM budgeted for increasing like Chuck said throughout the entire year.
Great. Can you put any color on the declines you're seeing from some of the wells that you've had on for some period of time now from the Big George?

Chuck, you might, on some of the wells – I mean, we are seeing some declines, but the way it works over there Brian, you create a big pressure sink and really seeing not a lot of wells have heavy decline yet, we're still seeing some good increases in wells. I mean, I'll add on I expect to see double-digit production growth from the CBM for 2008.
Our most matured property out there is the County Line – County Line unit, which is still increasing.

Okay. Switching to the Gulf of Mexico, a couple of unsuccessful wells in addition to the successful West Tongo well. What do the combination of the couple dry holes and the successes tell you about high grading or about the Miocene program in general?

This is Bob Daniels, Brian. We had a real successful well there at Tonga West and we're pleased with that, the Terrebonne and Atlas well – excuse me – were unsuccessful although we are going to take that information and tie it back into our interpretations and see where it leads us. Overall we've got a program out there and we are targeting the Miocene in the proven fairway. We think that if you look back at our track record there we've had just a tremendous run of success. And we don't think the two dry holes after the successful well will deter us at all, it's more what do we learn from them how do we roll back into our understanding and where is the next well that we are going to drill that we'll pursue what we have learned from those.
Great and are you still contemplating potentially selling an interest in some of your lower Tertiary success?

We have got a fantastic lower Tertiary position out there, both acreage position and prospects and we are constantly looking at what is the best way to monetize that; clearly the lower Tertiary has advanced, but it's advancing slowly and we would like to see more value created out of that portfolio. So, we are looking at all sorts of different ways of doing that. We will be drilling three lower Tertiary tests this year and we will continue to evaluate what that means for us as a company going forward and what that position can yield in a way of value to us.

Brian, I might add; you have seen us in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico on our assets, the way we manage our portfolio is trying to maintain a 20 to 40% type working interest position. And I would expect us to maintain that philosophy going into lower Teritary too. So, in assets where we have a high working interest, you will see us sell down, trade, work some deals for other opportunities.
Thank you very much.
Your next question comes from the line of David Tameron with Wachovia. Please proceed.

Hi, good morning. Question, looking at 2008 CapEx, it looks like I think the number you threw out was 30 to 35% dedicated to Rockies. What percentage of cash flow comes from the Rockies, if you look at your '08 budget operating cash flow?

David this Al Walker. As you can imagine we don't give that type of field level data or regional data on a cash flow basis, but we do believe that we have good free cash flow coming out of the Rockies in general relative to the CapEx plan there as well as overall for the year. If you will get with us in March at our Investor Conference, at that time we'd probably give you a little more of the field level data you're looking for, but at this time until we file the K, we're really not in a position to talk about it in the detail you're looking for.
All right. Jim, can you clarify what you said about the reserve booking, you said infill drilling is now going to be classified by the SEC in the revisions category is that, is that the jist of it?
That is correct, and it is a change that you would not have seen us do last year or earlier years, and I might have Al expand upon why we came to that conclusion.

Yeah, David we felt like from the comment letter process one of our peers went through the SEC. The SEC was pretty clear in saying that infill wells and proven reservoirs are not extensions or exploration wells and therefore using the comment letter process that they went through and the way the SEC chooses then to have the rest of us understand how to apply that we thought it was pretty black and white on this issue. And so it's not so much an interpretation on o,ur part as it is the way the SEC is asking us to be able to demonstrate in our data the fact that in field wells and proven reservoirs are not extensions and exploration wells.

And David we felt strongly enough about making ourselves clear on this that we went back to our consulting engineers and asked them to go through their full staff and find out if there was any exception to that issue and their view was is that – that the interpretation they have given us about revisions is right on for what they view across the firm.

Yeah and then the only thing I would add further is that it just we feel like we more than replace our production in a process by which the reserves that we booked for the year more than exceeded the production for the year and for us that's the takeaway.

All right. Thanks and then one final question Jim. On looking back now year and a half later Kerr-McGee and Western Gas, is there, what asset surprised you the most as far as on the upside or downside? If you don't want me to give me a downside so I'll go with the upside?

Yeah. Well I think, there is several, but certainly the CBM has worked out to be a homerun for us, and in general the assets that Western held were when you look at some of the monetization work we have done, and what we are planning to do with our midstream business, I think you'd have to say that had a pretty, is going to have a pretty quick payback.

The thing we like about the Kerr-McGee assets in addition to a lot of operational diversity is the long dated nature of what we're doing in areas like Greater Natural Buttes and the development potential we have in some of the other areas we were lucky enough to keep and acquire. I think both of those transactions have turned out in retrospect to even be better than any of us had imagined at the time.

Jim, I would like to put a plug-in for the Wattenberg asset because with higher than expected oil prices and the fact that that field generates 25 to 30% of its hydrocarbon from the liquid basis has really made the economics of Wattenberg much more attractive than we ever thought they would be.
All right; thanks and congrats on a nice quarter and a good year-end.
Thanks Dave.
Your next question comes from the line Gil Yang with Citi. Please proceed.
Hi, good morning. A couple of questions, do you comment on why the tax rate was so high and why the guidance is high going forward?

Yeah Gil for the quarter, Algeria since the EPT portion that we record in production taxes is not deductible and Algeria therefore is not a deductible in the states. Our tax rate will above the statutory rate as long as that's in effect. Even taken that into account though the fourth quarter was a little bit higher than we'd anticipated and really that was really some true-ups as you go through the year and you're working on your state and trying to get everything cleaned up we did have some incremental taxes come through on the quarter which happened to raise that the tax rate. Looking into 2008, Gil; that is solely attributable to the Algerian EPT.
Okay. So, the effect would be that the higher oil prices are the higher your taxes rates will be. Is that right?
Yeah, that is correct.

Okay. Second question Jim is that, you've made fair comment that your LOE was down because of the higher volumes with little incremental fixed costs. What is the source of the guidance upward then sequentially going from fourth quarter into 2008 in that LOE?
That's a good question; I will let Chuck do that.

Gil, what we saw through the course of 2007 was continuous improvement almost quarter-over-quarter. I give a lot of credit to our field teams and engineering teams that helped this improvement happen. We were able to pull a lot of synergy through the combination of the three companies into our field operations, which gave us a great benefit that we didn't anticipate during the course of the acquisitions. Looking into 2008, there is really three or four drivers that we see going forward.

The first is, as we mentioned early with regard to CBM, financially expanding our operations out there, increasing the number of units under dewatering. And so we see a considerable increase in our water production out there, which has an associated electrical cost associated with it. So, that's one source.

The second thing we have is some statutory maintenance requirements that are one-time events in both Algeria and in the Gulf of Mexico that we have coming in 2008 that won't be an ongoing operation. And then finally just across the board as we focus on our base production we are seeing more and more work overs in 2008 compared to the fourth quarter of 2007. So, the combination of those three will add incremental cost to our OpEx, all of which are substantial investments in our future.
Okay, that's very helpful Chuck. Can you comment on the maintenance for Algeria and Gulf of Mexico? Are they going to be lumpy or fairly evenly distributed through the year?

It's going to be – it's going to be mostly in the first half, but it's – it's going to occur throughout the year essentially in Algeria we have our major central producing facilities are going through their 10-year tune up and so we will have that going, ongoing starting late in the first quarter and lasting for two or three months. And then in the offshore we are doing just general maintenance on our major platforms that have been out there for a while.
Will there be an accompanying downtime, because of those maintenance operations?
It's already cooked into our guidance.

Okay. And Chuck, maybe this is a question – last question for you is can you give us an idea of what you expect from the three well program at Marco Polo what's going on with that reservoir and what's your evaluation of what the productivity of that reservoir is?

Well, what we did last year was we went back on to the platform drilled several infill wells, made completions that gave us a lot of optimism with regard to the future performance of the field. And so, what we will see in 2008 is essentially a continuation of that program. I know, we haven't released expectations with regard to the production, but the work we did last year was very profitable and we anticipate a continuation of that.
Is that just driven by the fact that the oil prices are high and so that you can target the compartments more economically?

That certainly helps, but we have great looking opportunities as we learned and produced the field, we've learned a considerable amount from the field production, and pressures and that type of thing and – we have lot of optimism with regard to its future.
All right. Thank you.
Your next question comes from the line Robert Christensen with Buckingham Research. Please proceed.
Yes. Can you please give us an update on your deepwater drilling rig contracts – number of rigs, time remaining in – whether they are still in the money?
We're trying to figure out who the best person to answer that is for you.
Daniels probably.
Well actually we're using the combination of Daniels and Meloy because there is...
We have number contracts with regard to deepwater rigs; I don't think we have the time to go through individual contracts on this call.
Yeah.
Yeah. Bob this is Colglazier, I will go ahead and get a schedule put up and we'll put it on the website just showing the nine rigs that we have under contract and their expiry dates.

Bob, at a high level, we feel like the rigs are still going to be heavily utilized, there is strong demand you can see that the utilization rate of deepwater, versus rigs and drill ships, are they – many of the rigs are substantially in the money and you have seen us extend some contracts and basically let some new contracts, so we expect to maintain our rig position going forward.

Yesterday, I read a story that of Algeria that they are soliciting foreign oil companies for participation in exploration bids – kind of amazed by that given their windfall profits tax surprised what 18 months ago. What's your take on that and would you participate in another round?

Yeah, we were aware that a next portion big round that they have planned and they are asking for prequalification for that. Of course the physical terms are going to be quite onerous compared to previous bid ramp in Algeria and it will be interesting to see what sort of competition there is for those blocks. We haven't seen actually even what the blocks are, so really it's very early in the process. We are just aware that they are going through it.
Thank you very much.
Your next question comes from the line of Joe Allman with JPMorgan. Please proceed.
Thank you good morning everybody.
Good morning Joe.
Could you talk about the cost environment especially for drilling and completing wells and also talk about what kind of field level efficiencies you guys are seeing?

I'll hit real quick on the cost environment obviously we see that deepwater cost markets are still increasing. Competition for rigs and services, we are talking about this morning we are seeing onshore probably a little bit of softening, but there are areas that it's kind of like real estate location, location, location there is some areas that we see high demand for services and costs are quite competitive for us right now. I think we have indicated we expect about a 5% increase in cost on the service sector for 2008.
Okay. Can you talk about any offsets related to the field level efficiencies?
We – we've got a program going on, Chuck why don't you talk about that?

Well what we have seen, as we have put these companies together we've had levels in opportunities such as Cardinal Drill where we had two different – two companies operate in the same field, we've been able to plan those. We've seen a lot of synergy offshore particularly with logistics and air services between the legacy Anadarko and Kerr Mc-Gee properties. So, we have been able to substantially offset the increases as been evidenced by our production – our operating performance in 2007.

Okay that's helpful, and then back to that issue of the positive reserve revision. Could you – could you talk, I mean, that was a pretty big number 724 Bcfe. Could you tell about – how much of that was related to the re categorization issue? And then how much was other stuff – price and performance and what not?

As we talked about we are not going to talk about the breakout of price performance but I'll reemphasis what Jim said in his comments early that even in excluding price revisions we more than replace production for 2007 the majority of that revision is due to infill wells.

Gotcha. And how much could you give us an estimate of how much would your production replacement have been higher if you didn't sell Genghis Khan and Knotty Head, and Big Foot. Can you just ballpark there?

That's a good question. Daniels keeps reminding me how much he would of added this year if we had kept those, but we haven't gone back and reviewed those Joe to see exactly how much reserves would have booked, that would have been, we acquired a full sanctioning program and accessing much more detail then we currently have been.

In addition, Joe we are not really sure we have good clarity as to exactly how the drilling that has occurred, excuse me, since we've sold that has proven up additional reserves or not. So, it really would be kind of difficult for us to assess exactly what those additional barrels would have looked like.

But I think it's fair to say that this year, we had not expected to have significant adds from the exploration side because we have delayed a lot of our drilling and we didn't have those wells coming in and the reserves from those discoveries coming into the – the picture for 2007.
Joe I appreciate you bringing that up, because obviously with those in our picture if they'd been included it would have been even more robust than we currently have delivered.

Okay, gotcha. And then in terms of, like drilling in the Gulf of Mexico if are there any constraints I mean, are rigs a bit constrained in terms of drilling more wells there because it sounds like you're diversifying your international program. I think Jim, I think you said you're going to drill a North Sea well right near that big Husky discovery and you're obviously active in China and so, what are the constraints to drill more wells in the deepwater Gulf?

We – we still see tightness in the rig market and mobilizing rigs to certain areas is still a critical planning issue for the industry. I think you referred to the Husky thing, it's in South China Sea right and then as you say I mean we are going to be active down in Brazil, and that is we are moving rigs in different places, which is with the magic of higher oil and gas prices has caused in our businesses as we don't have these regional rig markets anymore it's – it's a much different dynamic and it therefore the control of those rigs is still a very valuable asset in our mind.
Okay guys. Okay, so – so that is okay. So, that is a South China Sea well, not. Okay.
Yes.

All right. I got you. Okay and then lastly is, in one of your releases you talked about, acceleration of the big resource base being a big focus in 2008. Is that anything – is that any different than what you experienced in 2007 or prior?

No, I mean it's all about converting the resource right now. And being very capital efficient in how we do it. So, as you have seen in 2007, we are going to maintain high-level capital efficiency and continue to aggressively convert that resource base into proved developed reserves.

And what you see in exploration as an attempt to, as long as we can exceed our cost to capital on those projects is to still put even more on the books over time to give us even longer dated growth as well as, additional opportunities that we think we can try to convert in a variety of different ways as Bob mentioned.
Gotcha. All right.
We've seen a lot of value in this industry placed on discoveries and appraisals without ever bringing them into production and we like part of that aspect.
Gotcha. All right very helpful, thank you.
Your next question comes from the line of David Heikkinen with Tudor Pickering. Please proceed.

Good morning. I had one bigger picture question and when I listen to the call and the questions versus your peers, most peers have some shale gas exposure trying to get into new plays, hear a lot about Appalachian, Fayetteville, Woodford Barnett, West Texas. Do you guys feel like you missed that or are you trying to get into any new plays and would it be a surprise in '08 to say, you have started to get into shale gas resources?
Bob Daniels is shaler than you think, so I'll let him answer that question.

Yeah, this is Bob Daniels. We've got an onshore exploration program that we think is very robust actually. We spent last year kind of focusing down on where we think we can have the best success; we are playing some tight gas, we are playing shale gas and we are playing some fractured reservoirs, which – we do have established positions in the Black Warrior Basin, the Maverick Basin and a very nice position in the Appalachian Basin.

We are planning on drilling wells in the Appalachian Basin this year to test the shale play out there and we are very optimistic about what we are seeing from the industry activity and particularly where our acreage sets relative to that industry activity and our understanding of the shale play. So we, while we are not in the Barnett, we have been very actively pursuing and trying to understand the shale gas plays and where we may be able to get into those on a ground floor basis.
Where is your Appalachian acreage? Just the state even would be helpful?
